summary:
◈ Rishan armor set
◈

: 25% increase in physical and arcane defense  boosts latent Chimaeran abilities (such as Eclipse and...
caption:
◈ Rishan armor set ◈ :

  • 25% increase in physical and arcane defense
  • boosts latent Chimaeran abilities (such as Eclipse and Ensorcell)
  • 35% increase in dexterity
  • 20% increase in speed

[made of dark iridian alloy, dragon ash silk and Great Void gems.]

The armorset Dan uses most frequently in L.O.V and the one I pictured him as having equipped throughout the opening chapter of Caol Áit.
Inspired by Mark of Oxin’s Rishan as well as the dark aesthetics and eclipse imagery often referenced/associated with Dan.

(click image for full view version)

blog.name: helloandwelcometounlearned
blog.title: What, Like It's Hard?

title: Gaining Control
body:
Warning: v. long self-care post that hopefully doesn’t suck.

Don’t you hate it when your life is falling apart and you see those self-care posts? If you’re like me, I only like those posts when I’m feeling good about my self care in the moment. If I’m depressed or anxious or overwhelmed, they just make me feel like a failure? 

When I say “I spent 5 years struggling with my sense of self”, it may not seem like a big deal, but I’m going to be 30 in 2020. As of right now, 5 years is more than 1/6 of my existence on this earth. That’s a long time to go on hating yourself.

So what did I do? I’m going to tell you. If you’re in a bad place right now and don’t want to read, I’ve been in your shoes. Hopefully my writing style will make you not hate what I have to say. If it does, save it. It may help one day.

1) I went to therapy, but not until I was ready

Arguably all of my issues from 2012 - 2017 branched from one thing: I was raped in college and did not remember. My anxiety, depression, and tendency to panic all really kicked off after the trauma, but without remembering anything, I couldn’t pinpoint what was different from before. It messed with my relationships, my communication, my marriage, my self-confidence. It literally fucked up everything.

From 2014 to 2017, which covers when I met my now-husband until I started feeling better, he encouraged therapy constantly. It did wonders for him. Our sex life was non-existent because I couldn’t let anyone close to me and as our marriage started falling apart less than 3 years after we tied the knot, he REALLY started pushing it. I tried it a few times between those years, and nothing really ever came out of it.

But in the Spring of 2017, when I was triggered into remembering everything from the attack 5 years before, I knew it was time. I had this sudden, calm realization wash over me that I simply couldn’t do this by myself. I found a therapist, I found a listening ear, and I found a diagnosis. Most importantly, I found out that what I had (PTSD) was something other people also had; I found out I was not alone. 

2) I started believing I could do stuff, and I started wanting to do the best job I could

This, also, took a long time. The rape had taught me that I was not smart or well-rounded or strong. After all, if I was any of those things, I would have insisted that I go home right away. I would have not followed my friend upstairs to his room. I wouldn’t have done a lot of things.

Finding a good support system is CRUCIAL. After talking things through with my therapist and talking and journaling to myself, I finally felt like I was able to tell other people, and the more I talked about it, the better I felt. I wrote about it, I basically had to make my husband listen to me (that is a story for another time, but long story short, between the stresses of teaching, marriage, and no sex, he became an alcoholic), and I confided in my best friend what had happened. Just the act of being able to talk about it allowed me to understand that it wasn’t my fault. It helped me undo years of damaging thoughts and helped me unlearn some really terrible habits I had gotten myself into while thinking I wasn’t worth anything.

As I talked with them, worked it through via books and workbooks, and began working my ASS off at my job because it was the one place I could go where I didn’t have to let my past affect my present, I began realizing that I was capable of things. I was capable of being a good friend and coworker and boss. I was capable of making sound judgments.

I started taking pride in every aspect of my job, whether or not I wanted to really do them. Listening to 90 voice mails that were left over the course of 2 months on a phone where the voice mail indicator light was broken? That’s real shitty. But I was going to do it, and I was going to do it well. I felt like I could conquer anything and everything. That led to taking pride in every aspect of my life; walking the dog, grocery shopping, making appointments, watching Judge Judy.

I still don’t trust myself all the time, which I think is normal. But I’ve learned to:

- Not panic over things I cannot control at that moment (ie, work problems when I’m not at work)
- Allow myself to make mistakes
- Maintain my “box”

(my box is in my car. when i leave for work, i place all my home issues in the box and when i arrive at work, i collect my work issues. then when i get back in the car on the way home, i place all my work issues in the box and when i get home, i collect my home issues. this way i can really enjoy my 40 minute commute to work and think about other, peaceful things. this is IMMENSELY helpful for me.)

3) I started Living my Truth (x)

I’ve been in the Phandom for nearly 10 years now, but nothing ever spoke to me the way that Dan Howell’s video about living your truth did. I’ve been writing for 17 years, and publication has always been a major goal for me. Suddenly, in a video from a nerd who I had watched while maturing and growing up - not to mention in the darkest phases of my life - he was encouraging his fanbase to do what they loved, and to live the life they wanted to despite what anyone else thought.

So I did just that. I maintained (and am still maintaining) the highest standards for myself at work, I’m living the kind of life I want to live at home, and I’m unabashedly writing my butt off. I’m submitting to expeditions and I’m telling everyone about my writing goals and I’m not ashamed to promote this silly habit that I love so much.

4) I actually started romanticizing simple things

This is a very recent thing (like, beginning of 2019, 10-days-old new) but my life has definitely changed. I took inspiration from a post about how you should live your life like a Studio Ghibli movie. Romanticize all the little things you do and make them truly enjoyable. I do just that.

- I no longer go to Starbucks. Instead I make a pot of tea and heat it up each morning and start my commute with fresh hot liquids and some sort of music/podcast
- I started bullet journaling. It’s not pretty, but it’s functional, and the hobby and habit tracker requires me to take time (maybe not every day because hey, life’s crazy sometimes!) to review the past days and how I’ve felt
- I tidy every day. I used to not do this, but between enjoying putting things in their place (the type-A part of me) and the fact that it makes my husband so happy, I’m starting to make it a habit, and a habit that I really like doing

I hope this gives you a little hope, you there, person who is struggling and who feels betrayed by their own mind. Remember you’re not alone, there’s no timeline to figure out your life, and the crappy feelings you have now, so when you dig yourself out, you can be proud of where you came from.

This, also, took a long time. The rape had taught me that I was not smart or well-rounded or strong. After all, if I was any of those things, I would have insisted that I go home right away. I would have not followed my friend upstairs to his room. I wouldn’t have done a lot of things.

Finding a good support system is CRUCIAL. After talking things through with my therapist and talking and journaling to myself, I finally felt like I was able to tell other people, and the more I talked about it, the better I felt. I wrote about it, I basically had to make my husband listen to me (that is a story for another time, but long story short, between the stresses of teaching, marriage, and no sex, he became an alcoholic), and I confided in my best friend what had happened. Just the act of being able to talk about it allowed me to understand that it wasn’t my fault. It helped me undo years of damaging thoughts and helped me unlearn some really terrible habits I had gotten myself into while thinking I wasn’t worth anything.

As I talked with them, worked it through via books and workbooks, and began working my ASS off at my job because it was the one place I could go where I didn’t have to let my past affect my present, I began realizing that I was capable of things. I was capable of being a good friend and coworker and boss. I was capable of making sound judgments.

I started taking pride in every aspect of my job, whether or not I wanted to really do them. Listening to 90 voice mails that were left over the course of 2 months on a phone where the voice mail indicator light was broken? That’s real shitty. But I was going to do it, and I was going to do it well. I felt like I could conquer anything and everything. That led to taking pride in every aspect of my life; walking the dog, grocery shopping, making appointments, watching Judge Judy.

I still don’t trust myself all the time, which I think is normal. But I’ve learned to:

- Not panic over things I cannot control at that moment (ie, work problems when I’m not at work)
- Allow myself to make mistakes
- Maintain my “box”

(my box is in my car. when i leave for work, i place all my home issues in the box and when i arrive at work, i collect my work issues. then when i get back in the car on the way home, i place all my work issues in the box and when i get home, i collect my home issues. this way i can really enjoy my 40 minute commute to work and think about other, peaceful things. this is IMMENSELY helpful for me.)

3) I started Living my Truth (x)

I’ve been in the Phandom for nearly 10 years now, but nothing ever spoke to me the way that Dan Howell’s video about living your truth did. I’ve been writing for 17 years, and publication has always been a major goal for me. Suddenly, in a video from a nerd who I had watched while maturing and growing up - not to mention in the darkest phases of my life - he was encouraging his fanbase to do what they loved, and to live the life they wanted to despite what anyone else thought.

So I did just that. I maintained (and am still maintaining) the highest standards for myself at work, I’m living the kind of life I want to live at home, and I’m unabashedly writing my butt off. I’m submitting to expeditions and I’m telling everyone about my writing goals and I’m not ashamed to promote this silly habit that I love so much.

4) I actually started romanticizing simple things

This is a very recent thing (like, beginning of 2019, 10-days-old new) but my life has definitely changed. I took inspiration from a post about how you should live your life like a Studio Ghibli movie. Romanticize all the little things you do and make them truly enjoyable. I do just that.

- I no longer go to Starbucks. Instead I make a pot of tea and heat it up each morning and start my commute with fresh hot liquids and some sort of music/podcast
- I started bullet journaling. It’s not pretty, but it’s functional, and the hobby and habit tracker requires me to take time (maybe not every day because hey, life’s crazy sometimes!) to review the past days and how I’ve felt
- I tidy every day. I used to not do this, but between enjoying putting things in their place (the type-A part of me) and the fact that it makes my husband so happy, I’m starting to make it a habit, and a habit that I really like doing

I hope this gives you a little hope, you there, person who is struggling and who feels betrayed by their own mind. Remember you’re not alone, there’s no timeline to figure out your life, and the crappy feelings you have now, so when you dig yourself out, you can be proud of where you came from.
